speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the neck swelling? How long have you been experiencing it and has it changed in size or color over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been about 2 months now, and I've noticed it's been steadily getting bigger. It's not really changed in color, but it's become a bit more noticeable because I've been looking at it in the mirror more often."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and if you've noticed any pain or discomfort in the area of the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been pretty active, still working as a traffic warden and trying to squeeze in a round of golf whenever I can. To be honest, I haven't really felt any pain associated with it, just a bit of stiffness when I move my neck. Nothing that's really bothered me too much, though."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it's been steadily increasing in size, but you haven't experienced any significant pain or discomfort. Can you tell me more about the sensation in the swelling - is it tender to the touch, or does it feel more like a firm lump?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels kind of firm, but not really tender. I can press on it and it doesn't feel like it's going to give way or anything, but at the same time, it's not really soft or squishy either. It's just a solid, sort of... bulge, I suppose."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your neck movements - do you find that the swelling shifts or feels more prominent when you turn your head to the left or right, or when you nod your head up or down?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it doesn't seem to shift much when I turn my head, but I do feel like it becomes more noticeable when I'm looking straight ahead. It's almost like it's pulling my skin upwards, but that's not a very precise way to describe it. I guess it's just that when I'm standing still, the swelling is more prominent in my line of sight."

speaker: Doctor
text: So the swelling seems to be more prominent when you're standing still and looking straight ahead. Can you tell me more about your overall health - have you noticed any other symptoms, such as fever, fatigue, or weight loss? And while we're on the topic of your overall health, I'd like to take a look at your neck and perform a quick examination. Please lift your shirt and let me take a look.

speaker: Patient

I'll make sure to keep an eye on it, though." "Now, please go ahead and take a look. I'm ready when you are."

speaker: Doctor

text: "Okay, I'll tilt my head to the left... and to the right. *tilts head* It doesn't seem to shift much, but I can see how it's more noticeable when I'm looking straight ahead. As for when I first started noticing it, I think it was about a month ago when I was working as a traffic warden. I was standing still, just scanning the traffic, and I caught a glimpse of myself in a reflective vest. That's when I noticed the swelling was more prominent than usual. I didn't think much of it at the time, but now that you mention it, it was a bit of a surprise."

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Patient
text: "Ah, yeah, I do stand for long periods of time, especially during peak hours when I'm directing traffic. And I do have to wear a uniform that's a bit tight, so I'm pretty sure it's not that. But I do try to take breaks and move around every now and then. I've also been playing golf a lot lately, which involves a lot of walking and bending, but I don't think that's had anything to do with the swelling." "Okay, that helps to rule out any job-related trauma. Now, let me ask you this - have you noticed any changes in your overall posture or alignment, like if you've been leaning to one side more than the other?" "Actually, now that you mention it, I have noticed that I've been leaning a bit more to my left side when I'm standing or sitting. I don't know if that's related to the swelling, but I've just sort of gotten used to it over the past few weeks."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Ah, interesting, you've noticed a slight lean to your left side. text: "It's more like my body is leaning that way, I suppose. text: "I see, so you've been managing your diabetes as usual and adjusting your medication dosage as needed. That's good to know. I'd like to ask a few more questions to help clarify things. speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome with a possible underlying lymphatic malformation. Now, let me explain the diagnosis to you. Based on the patient's symptoms, including the numbness or tingling sensations in the left hand, particularly when gripping or lifting objects, and the dull ache in the left hand, I believe the patient is suffering from Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. This condition is caused by compression of the median nerve in the wrist, which can be exacerbated by activities that involve repetitive motion or heavy lifting. The patient's history of golfing, gardening, and lifting heavy objects, which involve gripping or lifting, may be contributing to the development of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. The presence of lymphadenopathy and the ultrasound findings of a well-circumscribed lesion in the subcutaneous tissue suggest that there may be an underlying lymphatic malformation or cystic lesion that is contributing to the swelling. I would recommend further evaluation and treatment to address the Carpal Tunnel Syndrome and the possible underlying lymphatic malformation. This may include physical therapy, wrist splinting, and possibly surgery to relieve the compression on the median nerve.
